newsitem.title: VATICAN: Pope appeals for calm in Brazzaville.
newsitem.headline: Pope appeals for calm in Brazzaville.

text.p: Pope John Paul appealed to the warring factions in Congo's divided capital Brazzaville on Sunday to stop fighting and take up the challenge of a peaceful solution.

Speaking to pilgrims and tourists in St Peter's Square for his Sunday blessing, the 77-year-old Pontiff expressed concern that the conflict was blocking mediation efforts and the work of humanitarian organisations.

"I add my voice to the appeals by the bishops of Congo so that so many brothers and sisters may be spared suffering and so much mourning and that a peaceful solution to the crisis can be found soon," he said.

Congo's divided capital enjoyed a second morning of relative calm on Sunday as supporters of President Pascal Lissouba and rival backers of former military leader Denis Sassou Nguesso observed a new ceasefire.

Hundreds of people have died since the fighting began on June 5. Efforts to broker a political solution, centred around conditions for fresh presidential elections, due on July 27 but postponed by the fighting, have made little progress.
